turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Hello Bud, I'm Lisa, a friend of Gordon's.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Lisa. Gordon? Oh, Mr. Gekko. Sure. Would you, uh, like to come in?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Didn't he tell you?  That's so like Gordon. Get dressed, we're going out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: We are?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So, where are we going?

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Wherever you like, Lutece, 21, the River Cafe...or maybe we can just drive around for a while.  Work up an appetite.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: Want some?  Gordon tells me you're a very talented broker. What do you like?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Like? Uh...hmmm. Well...

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: I got this guy who should know tells me buy Hewlitt Packard but I been burned on tips. What do you think Bud?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Let's see, it closed at uh, 41 1/8...  Up a quarter...very attractive... about average yield...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Rising profits...strong balance sheets, good earnings per share.

turns.speaker: LISA
turns.text: So you're hot on this stock?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's ready to take off. I'd jump all over it if I were you.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well we're thinking of putting up a statue of you in the subway. I hear you're moving up in the world. An associate already. Not bad. How's Margie?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Can't complain. Got a house in Oyster Bay. Market treating you good? Still seeing that sexy French gal?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Nah, she asked the wrong question.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: "What are you thinking?"...that was it. The hours are hell, but the money's starting to tumble in. I know this guy who's got an iron- clad way to make money, I can't lose and I can't get hurt.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: So, does "this guy" have a tip for an honest lawyer?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, check out Teldar Paper, it's still not over.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What about you, I hear you guys are handling the Fairchild Foods merger and it may not be going through. Any surprises I haven't read about in the Wall Street Journal?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Come on Buddy, you wouldn't want to got me disbarred now would you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who's listening? It's just one college buddy talking to another.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Yeah, right...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Relax, Roger, everybody's doing it but you don't know, you don't know.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: ...and if I did, what's in it for moi?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: More money than you ever dreamed, Roger. And the thing is no one gets hurt...how bout a beer?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Too much to do...but I'll walk you out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...and you don't have to put up a dime, Roger.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: All right, Bud... let's do it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So what's the problem?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: ...got a strange call from the SEC. They asked to see my records... Bud, this is a heavy...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ....Relax Roget  You're 82M in the account numbers and I'm the Invisible Man... they're always looking for red flags, Gekko's always getting checked by them, they never come up with anything... we're invulnerable on this...

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Alright... I just wanna slow down Bud... no more calls for awhile, no lunches... we suspend our business, alright...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure Roger, whatever you want, it's cool.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Gekko asked us into the Bluestar deal. We're reviewing the timetables, wanna come?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: He never told me...

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: You're just the President of the company, what do you know? ... Come on.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How do you do Mr. Gekko. I'm Bud Fox.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: So you say. Nice to meet you; hope you're intelligent. Like these, how'd you get these?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: So what s on your mind kimosabe? Why am I listening to you? Got to monitor my blood pressure, so whatever you do, don't upset me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh no, no...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Within 45 seconds, a microprocessor computes your systolic and diastolic pressure. Has an LCD readout, and it's cost effective -- less than one visit to the doctor.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I just want to let you know Mr. Gekko I read all about you at NYU Business, and I think you're an incredible genius and I've always dreamed of only one thing -- to do business with a man like you...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: So what firm you with, pal?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Jackson, Steinem...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...going places, good junk bond department, you got the financing on that Syndicam deal.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...Yeah, and we're working on some other interesting stuff.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...A cosmetics company by any chance? What are you, the 12th man on the deal team? The last to know?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Can't tell you that, Mr. Gekko.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: So whatta you got for me, sport? Why are you here?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Chart break-out on this one here...uh Whitewood-Young Industries...low P.E. Explosive earnings. 30% discount from book. Great cash flow. Coupla 5% holders. Strong management.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: It's a dog, what else you got, sport, besides connections at the airport?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...rings a bell somewhere. So what?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: A comer. 80 medium-body jets. 300 pilots, flies northeast, Canada, some Florida and Caribbean routes... great slots in major cities...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...don't like airlines, lousy unions...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: There was a crash last year. They just got a favorable ruling on a lawsuit. Even the plaintiffs don't know.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I know...the decision'll clear the way for new planes and route contracts. There's only a small float out there, so you should grab it. Good for a five point pop.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: My home number's on the back...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Bud Fox, I look at a hundred ideas a day. I choose one.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Hi sport.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Nice to see you again Mr. Gekko.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: See this? Can you believe it? Two inch screen...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...I can't even see it...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...for my kid Rudy -- 3 years old, electronics freak, got a liquid crystal display 'stead of an electronic beam. We're going into a new age pal. So how's business today.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Bluestar was at 21 and an eighth when I left the office. It might spin up to 25 by the bell...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Teldar's shooting up. Buy any for yourself? Bet you were on the phone two minutes after you got out of my office.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No sir, that would've been illegal...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Sure...relax sport, no one's gonna blow a whistle. Here, is this legal?...you wanna put it in my account?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Gekko -- thank you for the chance. You won't regret this, you're with a winner.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...put the rest of it in a money market account for now. I want to see what you know before I invest it...and save the cheap salesman talk, it's obvious.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Excuse me sir.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...come on sport, you gotta try harder, I need some exercise for chrissake...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Gekko, I don't think I can...go on.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...finish out the game, Bud, push yourself...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Nice club, Mr. Gekko...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Yeah... not bad for a City College boy. Bought my way into this club and now every one of these ivy league schmucks is sucking my kneecaps...I just got on the Board of the Zoological Society, cost me a million; that's the thing with WASPS -- they like animals but they can't stand people!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Uh, Mr. Gekko, we took a little loss today. We got stopped out on Tarafly...  ...about 50 thousand.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I guess your father's not a union representative on that company.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What? How do you know about my father?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: The most valuable commodity I know of is information. Wouldn't you agree on that?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Know the name?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: 'Course. Larry Wildman. One of the first raiders.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Sir Larry Wildman. Like all Brits he thinks he was born with a better pot to piss in... bribed an old secretary of mine to open bar mouth and stole RDL Pharmaceuticals right out from under me. Wildman the white knight.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I remember that deal. You were involved?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport.  ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world...  Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I...  It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that?  I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What about hard work?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: What about it? You work hard. I'll bet you stayed up all night analyzing that dog you bought. And where'd it get you?... my father worked hard too like an elephant pushing electrical supplies. And he dropped dead at 49 with a heart attack and a tax bill and the bank pissed on his grave and took the house; my mom ended up working in a dish factory... Wake up pal, if you're not inside you're outside. And I'm not talking a $200,000 a year working Wall Street stiff flying first class and being "comfortable", I'm talking rich pal, rich enough to fly in your own jet, rich enough not to waste time, 50-100 million, a player Bud -- or nothing. You had what it takes to let through my door. Next question: You got what it takes to stay...??

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I got all I could get which was 750,000 shares plus 5000 March 50 calls. Average price of $47 a share And $4 per contract for the call. I just wish I could've got more.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Don't expect to get it all, sport, you'll burn out. First rule of business is never get emotional about stock, clouds the judgment. Where do we stand?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I'll be right there, fix them a drink.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...we have 37.2 million invested. At this point, we're up 3.1 million and some change. If it goes to 75 bucks we can clean close to 12 mill.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You're walking between the raindrops kid. I expect Sir Larry is choking on his royal chamber pot by now.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: My firm needs your signature on these option agreements tonight, sir, otherwise we could take a real bath tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: ...Can't it wait? I'm good for it.  ...Awright. Come out, get the directions from Natalie and hurry up.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sorry, Mr. Gekko.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Allright. Wait here...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I guess I'll head back...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Stick around... Larry, one of my "gang" -- Bud Fox.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The break up value is higher. It's worth 80.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: But we don't want to be greedy now, so let's let him have it at $72.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: He's right. I had to sell. The key to the game is your capital reserves. You don't have enough, you can't pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: "All warfare is based on deception..." Sun Tzu says, If your enemy is superior, evade him, if angry, irritate him, if equally matched, fight... if not, split and reevaluate.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You're learning, sport...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Money never sleeps pal. When I came in in '69, they traded six hours a day, now the clock don't stop, London's deregulated, the Orient is hungrier than us. Just let the money circle the world, sport, buying and selling, and if you're smart it comes back paying. I just made $800,000 in Hong Kong gold. It's been wired to you -- play with it. You done good, but you gotta keep doing good. I showed you how the game works, now school's out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Gekko, I'm there for you 110%.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You don't understand. I want to be surprised...astonish me, sport, new info, don't care where or how you get it, just get it... My wife tells me you put a move on Darien. Here's some inside info for you. That Euroflash GQ guy she's going with's got big bucks but he's putting her feet to sleep. Exit visas are imminent. So don't lose your place in line.  Oh, jeez, I wish you could see this. The lights coming up over the water. I've never seen a painting that captures the beauty of the ocean at this moment.  ...an old Russian proverb - "a fisherman always sees another fisherman from afar." I like you sport, I ever tell you that... Gordon, call me Gordon from now on.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...Gordon.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Yeah, I'm gonna make you rich, Bud Fox. I'm gonna make you rich enough you can afford a girl like Darien. Remember, power is the best aphrodisiac. This is your wake-up call. Go to work.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Got him at an auction in Kentucky.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Close to two million.  But this sucker can go all the way to Devon and the nationals.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: The art of which is deception. Spread the buy orders through different accounts and you won't get burned...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I think I got some friends that won't mind making some easy money...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Mixed emotions, Buddy: like Larry Wildman going off a cliff in my new Maserati. Men as smart as myself have got their asses handed to them on a sling with the airlines, fuel could go up, unions are killers...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah aren't you forgetting something Gordon: rule one, capital reserves. This company has $75 million cash in an overfunded pension. That buys us a lot of credibility...  ...and the beauty is you already own close to two percent of this sucker...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gordon what I want--and I never asked you for anything--is to be your co-pilot on this. I want to take this airline, turn it around, and make it work. It's gonna make us a fortune!

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I'm talking to a stockbroker who wants to run an airline. It's gonna take me two years and 2000 headaches to turn Teldar Paper around, what do I need this dink airline for? I'm up to my ass in more nuts than a fruitcake.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gordon, I worked at Bluestar, I know my way around, I have friends there...inside.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The three unions. It's 43% of Bluestar's operating budget, the hourly cost of a flight crew is $850 an hour, that's the real hidden value G.G., if you can negotiate that out, get a crew down to $350-400 an hour a run, this airline is gonna be the hottest thing since Texas Air...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: What makes you think you can?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I can talk to these people Gordon, they trust me...and my father can be a big help in getting cuts.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Alright... Susan, get Buckingham on the box. I want him to look at it. And tell Jock Taylor at Thwick, Jensen...  So sport, the falcon has heard the falconer...tell me more...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: And I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Gekko, and his lawyer, Mr. Salt.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: A pleasure to meet you, Mr. Fox.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Now, wait a minute, Dad...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Sure. What's worth doing is worth doing for money. It's a bad bargain where nobody gains. And if this deal goes through, we all gain.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I didn't know we had a meeting schedule for this morning.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm sorry, this can't wait.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: What the hell do you want?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I found out about the garage sale down at Bluestar. Why?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Last night I read Rudy the story of Winnie the Pooh and the Honey pot. Know what happened: he stuck his nose in that honey pot once too often and got stung.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Maybe you ought to read him Pinocchio. You told me you were going to turn Bluestar around. Not upside down. You used me.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You're walking around blind without a cane, sport. A fool and his money are lucky to get together in the first place.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why do you need to wreck this company?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Because it's wreckable. I took another look and I changed my mind.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: If these people lose their jobs, nowhere to go. My father worked at Bluestar for twenty-four years. I gave 'em my word.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: It's all about bucks, kid, the rest is conversation...  Bud, you're still going to be president. And when the time comes, you'll parachute out a rich man. With the money you're going to make, your father won't have to work another day in his life.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Tell me, Gordon--when does it all end? How many yachts can you waterski behind? How much is enough?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Buddy, it's not a question of enough. It's a zero sum game, sport. Somebody wins and somebody loses. Money itself isn't lost or made, it's simply transferred from one perception to another. Like magic. That painting cost $60,000 10 years ago. I could sell it today for $600,000. The illusion has become real. And the more real it becomes, the more desperately they want it. Capitalism at its finest.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How much is enough Gordon?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: The richest one percent of this country owns half the country's wealth: 5 trillion dollars. One third of that comes from hard work, two thirds of it comes from inheritance, interest on interest accumulation to widows and idiot sons and what I do -- stock and real estate speculation. It's bullshit. Ninety percent of the American people have little or no net worth. I create nothing; I own. We make the rules, Buddy, the news, war, peace, famine, upheaval; the cost of a paper clip.  We pull the rabbit out of the hat while everybody else sits around their whole life wondering how we did it...  ...you're not naive enough to think we're living in a democracy are you, Buddy? It's the free market. You're one of us now...take advantage of it. You got the killer instinct, kid, stick with me. I got things to teach you...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Obviously...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Believe me, Buddy, I was gonna discuss this with you at the right time. Look, why don't you calm down and come to the apartment for dinner tonight. Bring Darien...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...I can't make it tonight.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Are you with me Buddy?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gordon, it's two minutes to close. What do you want to do?! Decide.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Dump it.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Hello Bud.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Gordon.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You sandbagged me on Bluestar.  I guess you think you taught the teacher a lesson, that you can make the tail wag the dog, huh?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Hello again, I been holding these drinks for us for the last three weeks.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Grand Marnier. A romantic and tragic drink.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Oh yes, I remember you.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Destiny took us apart, but I knew it would bring us back together.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Aha. Poet or philosopher?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Stock broker. As in: never have so few done so little for so much. So what do you see in this?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I'd give anything to have this in my house, even for a week.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...few thousand dollars down the drain if you ask me.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Oh really?  Well, I guess you can kiss that career as an art appraiser goodbye, because we paid over four hundred thousand for it at the contemporary picture sale last June.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You could have a great beach house for that.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Sure you could, in Wildwood, New Jersey. If you sold this,  you could have a pretty nice penthouse on Fifth. But you wouldn't have much left over for decoration.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Boy, I thought Gordon was a tough businessman, but somebody's really taking him to the cleaners here.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Not really. I'd say that Gordon is one of the most astute collectors around. He has a great eye and he only buys the best. Like this rug for instance, a silk Tabriz, the finest of its kind. The day after he bought it in London, a dealer representing the Saudi Royal Family offered him twice what he paid. It absolutely makes the room. See how this little bit of celadon in the border is picked up in the cushions oh the sofa... although...  I don't know if I would have used that tea dipped linen for the upholstery - too dingy. And it's a sacrilege having that Pre-Columbian pot in the center of the coffee table. Some dope might use it as an ashtray.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I gather you're a decorator.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You got it, a great spender of other people's money.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, if you're that good, you could probably do wonders at my place.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Upper West Side.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Oh really. Home of the exposed brick wall and the  houseplant.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh it's just a rental. I'm moving to the East Side soon. I've got a couple of deals brewing with Gordon.  but that's just conversation... what about real things? Like dinner. The two of us. Friday. Cafe. Santo Domingo.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: What if I have a previous engagement?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Break it.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I guess this must be destiny alright. My first yuppie apartment and...  my first yuppie.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You may call me a yuppie... It's Mister Yuppie to you.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So. See you Friday.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You really do believe in destiny?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Only if I want something bad enough.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Devon? He looks like Seattle Slew. What about the Triple Crown?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: He's not a racehorse, Bud, he's a jumper.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How would I know? I once bet a horse. He went out at ten to one and came in at quarter to five.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: If I could have anything... this would almost do.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, almost...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: So, how did your conference go with Gordon?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The conference, oh yeah. Fine. We reached an agreement and decided to divide up the world between us.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You have modest wants. I like that in a man.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: And what do you want?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: ...a Turner, a perfect canary diaiaond... a Lear jet... world peace... the best of everything...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, why stop at that?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're not trouble by any chance. Are you?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: ...isn't it perfect!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...too perfect...let's not even eat. Let's just watch it and think about it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know, the elevator man couldn't believe I paid $300,000 to have my walls looking like this, he's got them for free in Brooklyn.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I'll bet he's got an opinion on the stock market too. This apartment is already ahead of its time. I call it the "demolished" look. They've already heard about it at House and Garden and they're coming next week to photograph it before it gets... lived in. Is that alright? I'd love to have it in my portfolio.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure... But your fee... considering you're way over budget, should be negotiable.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Let's get things straight, Bud. I'm not going to take a cut. I worked hard and you can't decorate a room in New York for less than $100,000. Curtains alone...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm kidding, I'm kidding, we're still young, Darien. So what's money anyway when everybody's making it, it's all relative. After all, this is not the house in Connecticut, this is just a crash pad good for a couple of years...before we slip our two lovely kids, Yuppie and Fruppie into the Lycee Francaise.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You got it all charted out don't you, like a stock projection.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's right -- one with high yield, rich assets and no downside...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Do you think you're ready?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's not me I'm worried about...You know Darien, the only reason we haven't slept together is because we both know we will -- and not knowing when was the only surprise left. You owe me, I want you, what else is there...but you, me, the world.  ...right here...make love to me...now...  Stop me if I'm going too far.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I'll let you know.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Bud, I hate to tell you this but you're a genius!  Darien...lightning has struck! The lightbulb has been invented. Edison, Da Vinci, Einstein are watching...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: ...are you going to trade all night again? You got to go to work in a couple of hours.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You think I'm gonna broker the rest of my life... I'm going to be a giant, Darien, an entrepreneur in the Italian 15th century sense of the word -- a mover, shaker.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I love you, baby. Did I tell you that sometime in the last 24 hours?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Get in bed. Y'ever hear of the sixty hour work week? You're turning into a yuppie Frankenstein, you love money so much.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure, why not, money's the sex of the 80's. I never had it like you when I was growing up, baby, it wasn't the upper east side.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You're so naive Bud, you don't even know. Your dad took care of you. I might've been rich when I was a kid...but my father lost all his money...in the seventies, in the stock market, at the track. He was a lousy gambler...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...that changes all my plans, I thought you were loaded...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: So did I, till I hit 19 and found I had all the royal habits and no throne. Mom got by but I had to go to work just like you. Only the skills I had were shopping and making friends. So...that's why I do what I do, what makes you tick, Buddy?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Fear. The fear of being poor I guess, just like you, Darien... But that's all gonna change sweetheart. I'm catching the express...  ... and you're going along for the ride.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I'm sorry. I was afraid something like this could happen.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Talk about being bent over the sink of life and being dry humped. I handed it to him on a silver platter. I told my father and those people...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Buddy, it's not your fault, and it's not your decision.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm not gonna let it happen Darien.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Don't cross Gordon. He'll crush you. You've worked hard to get where you are. If Gordon doesn't buy Bluestar someone else will; and who's to say they won't do the same thing.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: At least I wouldn't be pulling the trigger.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Are you mad! Why are you doing this! We're so close, the town is going to be ours. Don't throw away your future Bud!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I can stay with the brokerage firm. And you're doing fine. We can survive without Gordon Gekko.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I'm not looking to just survive. I've been doing that all my life.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What the hell's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You really mean that?  What'd he promise you? To take you public? I guess without Gordon's money and seal of approval, I'm not such a hot investment anymore. You're just the best money can buy, Darien...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You're not exactly pure Bud, you went after Gekko with the same vengeance you went after me. Look in the mirror before...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm looking...and I sure don't like what I see.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You may not believe this Bud but I really do care for you. I think we could've made a good team...but that's how it goes...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Get the hell out!

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I figure a guy who's made some mistakes should be able to understand a girl who's made some of her own...

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: How you doing Buddy?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Great Carolyn, doing any better would be a sin...

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Morning Buddy, you look happy.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Any better and I'd be guilty.

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: You were never that innocent sugarpie.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...how do you know? You wish...

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: Bud! Where you been the last two days?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...Janet get my father on the phone and the two other union reps, urgent...

turns.speaker: CAROLYN
turns.text: He had a heart attack, hon, but he's okay, he's at the hospital...

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh Christ!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You got a look in your eye, Mr. Mannheim... You got something for the small fry...

turns.speaker: MANNHEIM
turns.text: Jesus, can't make a buck in this market, country's going to hell faster than when that sonofabitch Roosevelt was around... too much cheap money sloshing around the world. The biggest mistake we ever made was letting Nixon get off the gold standard. Putney Drug--you boys might want to have a look at it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sleep with me and the secrets of the West are yours.

turns.speaker: MANNHEIM
turns.text: Now that's a crap company, sure you'll make money on the takeover rumor, but what's being created. Nothing. No substance behind it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Old values. Buy.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Mannheim, got a sure thing.  Anacott Steel.

turns.speaker: MANNHEIM
turns.text: No such thing Bud - 'cept death and taxes. Not a good company anymore, no fundamentals. What's going on Bud? Do you know something?  Remember there're no short cuts son, quick buck artists come and go with every bull market but the steady players make it through the bear markets.  You're part of something here, Bud. The money you make for people creates science and research jobs. Don't sell that out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're right, Mr. Mannheim, but you gotta get to the big time first, then you can be a pillar and do good things.

turns.speaker: MANNHEIM
turns.text: Can't get a little bit pregnant, Bud.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's a winner Mr. Mannheim, trust me -- buy.

turns.speaker: MANNHEIM
turns.text: You're on a roll kiddo. Enjoy it while it lasts -- 'cause it never does.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: ...just kickin' ass and taking names, Mr. Mannheim.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I thought this was an informal meeting. What's he doing here?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Harold, you don't mind strolling around the block a couple hundred times, do you?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Frankly, Carl, I can't see giving much more. If you have any suggestions I'll be glad to listen.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: There came into Egypt a Pharoah who did not know.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I beg your pardon. Is that a proverb?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: No, it's a prophecy. The rich have been doing it to the poor since the beginning of time. The only difference between the Pyramids and the Empire State Building is that the Egyptians didn't have unions.  I know what this guy is about-- greed--he's in and out for the buck and he don't take prisoners. He don't give a damn about Northstar or us ...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Fine, if you don't want us, stay with the scum in present management--dedicated to running you and Bluestar into the ground.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: ...that "scum" built this company up from one plane in thirty years, they made something out of nothing, and if that's a scum I'll take one over a rat any day...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: What do you say we go get a suite at the Carlyle? Caviar? Champagne? Celebrate, just like the old times Sunshine.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Those days are over, Gordon. They were over a long time ago.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Can't blame me for trying. You look as beautiful as that painting I just bought.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: So what's the problem Sunshine? You look like Black Thursday. Bad case of puppy love?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: It's not puppy love, Gordon. Anyway, Buddy and I are splitting up.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Sorry to hear that. I thought the kid had staying power.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: It's over you, Gordon.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You told him about us?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: No, are you crazy? And I don't want him ever to know. Do you understand?...

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I want to ask you a big favor, Gordon. Please drop the Bluestar deal.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Now tell me, why would I want to do that?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Because I don't want to see him hurt.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Don't worry Sunshine. Bud and I had a little talk. We came to an understanding.  I want you to go back to him. Soothe him. Help keep his head straight. Okay?

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: I can't...and I won't.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Come on, we both like Buddy. But this bleeding heart puppy love act is over the top... It doesn't fit.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: Maybe it does. Don't patronize me Gordon.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You and I are the same, Darien. We're smart enough not to buy into the oldest myth running: love... A fiction created by people who got nothing to keep them from jumping out of windows.

turns.speaker: DARIEN
turns.text: You're really twisted, Gordon. You're incapable of giving to anybody because deep down inside you there's a poverty that every last dollar in the world won't fill.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Ooh ooh, tough talk from a scared little girl all wrapped in a pretty grown-up package. Does this mean you're ready to cut the umbilical cord and step out into the world on your own? Because, Darien, if you're through with me, you're through with everything I'm a part of.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Yeah, Billy, who's your buyer?... No, not interested.  Ollie, start calling a the institutions, start with Marx at Janson Mutual, then Reardon. Get me that California retirement money, baby! And we're on our way!

turns.speaker: OLLIE
turns.text: You got it, G.G.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: He respond to the offer? What? What the hell's Cromwell doing giving lecture tours when his company's losing 60 million a quarter? I guess he's giving lectures on how to lose money...if this guy opened a funeral parlor, no one would die, this turkey's totally brain dead...Well Christmas is over and business is business.  Keep buying. Dilute the sonofabitch. Ollie I want every orifice in his body flowing red.

turns.speaker: OLLIE
turns.text: He's flowing, Gordo. Piece of cake.

turns.speaker: OLLIE
turns.text: ... just got 250,000 shares at 18 1/4 from Janson, think I'll pull twice that at 18 1/2 outta the California pensions. We got close to half a million shares in the bag.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Hey, the Terminator! Blow 'em away Ollie.

turns.speaker: OLLIE
turns.text: And, I'm pretty sure we got the Beezer Brothers out of Tulsa coming in with us and I'm working on the Silverberg boys in Canada.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Rip their throats out and put them in your garbage compactor.  Interesting. You got a card?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Rarest pistol in the world, Larry, a .45 Luger. Only six were ever manufactured.

turns.speaker: WILDMAN
turns.text: Congratulations but rarer still is your interest in Anacott Steel.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: The same interest as yours Larry. Money. I thought it'd be a good investment for my kid...

turns.speaker: WILDMAN
turns.text: No. This time I'm in for the long term. This is not a liquidation, Gordon. I'm going to turn it around. You're getting a free ride on my tail, mate, and with the dollars you're costing me to buy back the stock, I could modernize the plant. I'm not the only one who pays here Gordon. We're talking about lives and jobs; three and four generations of steel workers...

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You must be wearing a mask you're laughing so hard behind it Larry. Let's cut the "sir" crap. Correct me if I'm wrong, but when you took CNX Electronics, you laid off 8,000 workers, Jessmon Fruit about 6,000, that airline...

turns.speaker: WILDMAN
turns.text: I could break you, mate, in two pieces over my knees, you know it, I know it, I could buy you six times ever, I could dump the stock just to burn your ass but I happen to want the company and I want your block of shares. I'm announcing a tender offer at 65 tomorrow, and I'm expecting your commitment.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Considering you brought my mother into it, $71.50.

turns.speaker: WILDMAN
turns.text: Done. You'll hear from my lawyers. 8 a.m. Good night.

turns.speaker: WILMORE
turns.text: With all due respect, Mr. Gekko, what's to prevent you from doing the same thing?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Cause I have a way around all this, a way we can all make money and make this airline profitable again. What do you say we cut to the chase. I'm asking for a modest twenty percent across-the-board wage cut.

turns.speaker: WILMORE
turns.text: Are you prepared to put that in writing?

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: I'll have a letter of agreement drawn up within two days.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Cards are on the table. What do you think?

turns.speaker: WILMORE
turns.text: If you mean what you say, I think we're in the ball park. I'll take it to my people.

turns.speaker: WILMORE
turns.text: We know what you're up to, Gekko, and let me tell you this from here,  you suck eggs, mister, over my dead body you ain't gonna break up Bluestar.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: You guys must know something nobody else knows. If those are my plans, it's the first I've heard of it.

turns.speaker: GEKKO
turns.text: Listen, you clowns, there's somebody else out there trying to buy your airline, if you want to be Pac-manned and gobbled by Atilla the Hun be my guest!

turns.speaker: WILMORE
turns.text: We'll take our chances.  Nice to see you again, Mr. Gekko.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I saw the greatest movie with mark last night

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: With Mark?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: He still likes you

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Oh I don't give a shit the guy's a slob.  He doesn't even know how to spell  `lady' let alone treat me like one.  You know the last time we went out he  actually made me pay for a drink?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Yes, I'm sure.  What I need is an older man, something with class, a  little style. Someone who knows how to treat a lady.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Businessman?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Businessman!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Doctor? Lawyer? CHINA Lawyer, Doctor, I don't care.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, OK

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Yeah

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: So why are you dating Jonathan?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: But?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: But he still has something Mark hasn't.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: A body.  I mean we're talking major body

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Well that's for me to know - but I did enjoy rubbing oil all over that big.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Just give it a break China ok? CHINA Jeez.  Can't even take a joke

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Anybody want another drink?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: It's eleven forty-five let's go

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: We need to talk. CHINA Yeah about what?

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: About what?  About us.

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Us is over.  You had your chance you blew it.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Right. CHINA I need a taking care of,  not `hey how bout a pizza after class babe'.  I'm looking  for something just a little more in a man.  A little `je nes se qua'.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: A little what? CHINA See.  You don't even speak French.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: I'm sorry I'm not that good at languages ok?

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Yeah well why should I suffer for that?

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Suffer?  We're living in America.

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Well if you're in such a rush darling, why don't you lead the way?

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Ok toots, I will.

turns.speaker: CHINA
turns.text: Oh Mark.  It's ok.  It's ok.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: China.  What happened? CHINA Shhh.  It's ok.  I missed you so much.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR ROBERTS
turns.text: Weird and tiny huh?

turns.speaker: MR LINCOLN
turns.text: Hi

turns.speaker: MR LINCOLN
turns.text: Yes, it's always been one of my favorites too.

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR ROBERTS
turns.text: Hmm.

turns.speaker: MR LINCOLN
turns.text: Would you like a closer look?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR ROBERTS
turns.text: It's all rather morbid though isn't it?

turns.speaker: INSPECTOR ROBERTS
turns.text: Yes, I guess you're right

turns.speaker: MR LINCOLN
turns.text: Are you sure you wouldn't like a closer look?

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: Your books Master Loftmore

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Thank you Jenkins

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: And your coff - excuse me, caffeine sir

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Thank you

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: And uh, your nicotine sir

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Thank you

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: Allow me sir

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: Will you be wanting your wheels today sir?

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Uh, not today Jenkins, I need the fresh air

turns.speaker: JENKINS
turns.text: Have a nice day  sir
